div.head: h i g h l i g h t s
div.p: • A timely monitoring and diagnosis scheme is proposed based on virtual systems.
• Three types of process faults are studied, and corresponding optimized control configurations are proposed.
• Both reconfiguration problems of bias faults and apparatus failures are considered.
• Adaptive algorithms are integrated to design digital twins at both on-line and off-line stage.
• Proposed digital twins are appropriate for the dynamic systems with unknown model parameters.

div.head: Introduction
div.p: Process systems are complex socio-technical systems that are susceptible to catastrophic incidents due to inevitable processes, machinery, instrumentation, or human hazards [1]. Generally, the materials in process factories are toxic, flammable, and explosive, while the necessity of optimizing productions is forcing the operating condition to severe limits such as high pressure or high temperature [2]. Since the process industry has numerous sensors and actuators, once a fault is not detected and corrected, the process performance would deteriorate and further severe safety issues could occur [3]. In order to provide automatic security decisions during the operational stage in the context of industrial automation production, intelligent monitoring and control systems need to be developed and deployed [4].

Under the tide of the fourth industrial revolution, digital twins are of crucial importance for industrial automation. Digital twins describe the use of holistic simulations to virtually mirror a physical system [5]. Adopting digital twins allows operators to monitor productions, test deviations in an isolated virtual environment, and further strengthen the security of process industries [6]. Extending from the life-cycle design of process factories, Patterson et al. [7] propose an integrated nuclear digital environment linked to the real world. Longo et al. [8] introduce a physical modeling framework of digital twins for emergency management and decision-making in process industries. However, with the significant growth of process data, traditional model-based methods are impractical to describe the state-space of complex systems. Therefore, data-driven technology has become a potential solution to model digital twins for process industries [9]. In https://doi.org/10.1016/j.isatra.2019.05.011 0019-0578/© 2019 Published by Elsevier Ltd on behalf of ISA.

the early period, the multivariate statistical analysis reveals the effectiveness of data-driven technologies. Most related multivariate statistical works focus on condition monitoring and system diagnosis. Ding [10] and Yin et al. [11] survey the basic theory of data-driven methods for system monitoring, including principal component analysis (PCA), partial least squares (PLS), and generalized likelihood ratio (GLR). Kadlec et al. [12] discuss general soft sensor technologies for process monitoring and diagnosis. Severson et al. [13] summarize data-driven methods such as fisher discriminant analysis (FDA) and support vector machine (SVM) for the diagnosis design of digital systems. Zhang et al. [14] propose an extensible deep belief network (DBN) based fault diagnosis model for chemical processes. However, such multivariate statistical analysis and machine learning methods rely on a large number of multi-category fault data, which are difficult to collect. Besides, most related methods are limited to describe dynamical system status and cannot be applied for the real-time diagnosis. Concerned with the construction of digital twins, the subspace identification method (SIM) [15] describes the complex process through a state-space matrix, which provides an attractive virtual mirror for the MIMO system. Furthermore, Ding et al. [16] develop the SIM and propose an observer-based algorithm to deal with the data-driven design of process monitoring systems. Nevertheless, existing SIMs are difficult to construct available virtual models for complex closed-loop systems. Therefore an adaptive SIM needs to be developed to improve the identification performance for digital twins.

The intent of developing digital twins is to improve the security of process systems, and thus automatic fault-tolerant control (FTC) is one of the critical technologies for digital twins. FTC design enables process factories to continue its predetermined operation after the apparatus fails, possibly at a reduced level rather than a complete failure [17]. The FTC configuration generally consists of two strategies: the passive approach or the active one. The former employs the robustness of the closed-loop control system to accommodate faults, while the other scheme reconfigures the closed-loop control system after a fault occurs [18]. The FTC performance depends on the design of reconfiguring control gains. Reconfiguration approaches primarily comprise model-matching, pseudo-inverse, adaptive control, and model predictive control [19]. The passive control is limited in handling massive failures due to the insensitive robustness, while the active control scheme based on the Youla parameterization is efficacious in the reconfiguring control and attract widespread attention [20]. Ding et al. [21] equate the Youla parameterization controller with the observer-based controller, accordingly propose a flexible configuration for the FTC design using process data. Yin et al. [22] develop the observer-based framework and present iterative optimization methods to enhance system performances. Most FTC related literatures only consider bias and gain faults, while rarely pay enough attention to apparatus failures. Actuator failures cause the controller to be uncontrollable, which increases the difficulties of control reconfiguration. Wen et al. [23] propose an adaptive failure compensation scheme based on the linear-quadratic (LQ) control for discrete-time systems with unknown actuator failures. Teixeira et al. [24] integrate model-matching and LQ control to address the problem of distributed reconfiguration upon the removal of misbehaving sensors and actuators. However, previous control schemes base on preset reconstruction gains to improve control performance, while cannot automatically adjust the control gain according to the process diagnosis results. Besides, most control studies based on the concept of FTC aim for guaranteeing the stability of productions under faulty conditions, while ignoring the security of process systems.

Motivated by the studies mentioned above, the present paper proposes a data-driven digital twin architecture for the optimized control in process industries. Compared with existing applications, we emphasize the following contributions. (1) Proposed digital twins only rely on standard samples under stable productions, which is easy to collect. (2) Proposed digital twin technologies can be applied for dynamical systems with unknown model parameters, and simultaneously, adaptive algorithms are applied to realize offline and online optimization in the optimized control configuration. (3) The mechanical faults are divided into three categories: sensor fault, actuator failure, and process disturbance. The proposed control configuration not only considers the gain and bias faults, but also addresses the reconfiguration problem with uncontrollable actuators. (4) Differing from the previous contributions, the proposed optimized control configuration aims for guaranteeing stable operations and enhancing securities of control systems versus simply stabilizing productions by reducing disturbances.

The rest of the paper is organized as follows. In Section 2, process fault descriptions and problem formulations are first presented. Section 3 briefly introduces the critical digital twin technology, including the virtual system modeling, process monitoring, diagnosis, as well as the optimized control configuration. In Section 4, the fault identification scheme and the digital twin architecture are discussed. In Section 5, the case study on TE benchmark process is manifested. Finally, conclusions are made in Section 6.

div.head: Fault description and problem formulation
div.p: A fault in a dynamical system is a deviation of the system structure from the nominal situation. In general, the process faults comprise sensor faults, actuator faults, and plant faults [17]. Sensor faults include offset faults, drift faults, and complete failures, which typically manifest as additive faults. Actuator faults contain clogging faults, constant gain deviations, and failures, which generally manifest as multiplicative faults [25]. Since the actuator is entirely uncontrollable when an actuator failure occurs, we regard the actuator failure as a separate type of process faults. Besides, dynamical pressure fluctuations generated by external interferences at the inlet or outlet of the process could cause instability of the pressure-driven system, and therefore we incorporate the other actuator faults and the plant faults into a new type of faults as process disturbances. Ultimately, we divide the process faults into sensor faults, actuator failures, and process disturbance in present works.

Process faults can also be distinguished concerning their size and temporal behavior. To determine the applicability of proposed systems, we assume that all process faults are abrupt and occur in closed-loop systems. Since the compensation effect of the feedback control makes the closed-loop system have certain fault tolerances for incipient faults, we assume that all faults are significant and could cause obvious interferences to the system. Furthermore, the temporal behavior of the fault is assumed to be continuous. The control of intermittent faults requires constant initialization for reconfiguration controllers, so it cannot achieve satisfactory control performance, which will be discussed in Section 5.3.2. According to assumptions, the main topic of this paper is to develop an optimized control configuration to guarantee stable control performance under the above-mentioned fault scenarios.

As a result, under the condition that the parameters of the system plant model are unknown, this paper proposes an integrated digital twin system to achieve optimized control performances in system faulty cases. The design process of digital twin system is formulated as follows: First, the adaptive closed-loop SIM is applied to build the data-driven residual generator based on the virtual system modeling with unknown parameters of plant mod-els; Second, performance indices for abnormal status diagnosis are developed to enhance the identification performance of the process monitoring and diagnosis scheme; Finally, corresponding to different process faults, optimized control configurations are designed based on the offline adaptive tuning and online iterative training to improve the security under faulty conditions.

div.head: Virtual system modeling
div.p: When a process plant contains high-dimensional variables, huge computational overheads and memory issues could lead to inaccurate results. Referring to the Multi-block PLS process [26], the plant is first decomposed into meaningful blocks associated with a physical unit. To construct the virtual system, each plant block is modeled as the following form of discrete-time multivariable state-space:
div.formula: x(k + 1) = Ax(k) + Bu(k) + ξ (k) y(k) = Cx(k) + Du(k) + υ(k) (1)
div.p: where x(k) ∈ R n , y(k) ∈ R m , u(k) ∈ R l represent the vectors of the state variables, process outputs, and inputs respectively. ξ (k)∈ R n and υ (k) ∈ R m denote zero-mean standard distributed noise sequences. A, B, C, D are state-space matrices. It is assumed that the plant model is controllable and observable, and the data-driven virtual system designed in this work is implemented under actual operating conditions, where the measurement noise and the external disturbance are considered. Moreover, the state-space matrix A is assumed to be stable and non-derogatory [27]. When dealing with nonlinear systems, some nonlinear state-spaces [28,29] can be applied to model complex nonlinear characteristics. Besides, when the amount of monitoring data is quite large, a variable selection method [30] is necessary to reduce redundant information and useless variables. Remark 1. SIMs are typically exploited for characterizing system features by constructing residual signals. However, for MIMO systems, the application of a single residual signal will lead to imperfect monitoring performances [21]. Due to unknown system orders and closed-loop interferences, conventional SIMs would have difficulties selecting appropriate parameters to achieve acceptable residual results. Therefore, inspired by previous works [11,16,31], we develop a multiple adaptive SIM to model attractive virtual mirrors for the processing system.

Remark 3. From above process monitoring and diagnosis models, we have four different residual generators to identify the abnormal status for a process plant. All designed residual generators are generally computed simultaneously and sufficiently sensitive to sensor faults or actuator faults. However, different from the general application, the robust process diagnosis model may identify a single fault as multiple faults in the presence of external interferences and obtain an indecisive result. Besides, the alarm flooding [36] has caused residual models challenging to integrate into the automated control systems. As a result, we propose a robust process identification scheme in Section 4.1 to evaluate the residual generator individually for automated implementation.

div.p: Process control problems for the sensor fault can be formulated as: given the identified extended observability matrices Γ ⊥ s , Γ ⊥ s H u,s , process inputs u(k), and normal sensor signals y 1 (k), . . . , y j−1 (k), y j+1 (k), . . . , y m (k), to estimate the fault sensor signal y j (k). Different to the previous contributions [37,38], the soft-sensor proposed here aims to ensure the production stability and safety for process industries, rather than to create a simple signal estimator for hard-to-measure quantities.

div.head: Process disturbance
div.p: As demonstrated in Section 2, all unknown faults and partial actuator faults are considered as the process disturbance, since in this case all actuators can still be controlled. The optimized control configuration of process disturbances not only considers parameter updates under fault conditions but also is suitable for the stability control under normal conditions to prevent misdiagnosis. Therefore, the Youla parameterization based closed-loop control architecture shown in Fig. 1 is applied in this work. The core of the approach is the virtual system based realization of the Youla parameterization for all stabilization controllers [22]. Proposed control architecture can be applied to the complex process with open loop instabilities. div.head: Actuator failure
div.p: Despite the increased use of motor-driven valves, lift-type pneumatic control valves are still applied in most process control applications. The pneumatic control valve includes the air-toopen valve and the air-to-close valve, which is selected according to the safety factors [41]. Due to the signal interruption from the transmitter, the actuator typically fails, causing the valve to close or open and uncontrollable. The control strategy for the actuator failure can be formulated as minimizing the performance degradation by adjusting the available actuators u 1 (k), . . . , u j−1 (k), u j+1 (k), . . . , u l (k), to compensate the faulty actuator u j (k) [42]. The process control procedure for the actuator failure comprises two steps: evaluating the redundancy of the faulty actuator and performing the actuator reconfiguration.

div.head: Remark 5. Existing process control configurations focus only on bias and gain faults, with little attention to actuator failures.
div.p: In this work, we propose an optimized control strategy based on the residual signal to reconfigure control gain to guarantee acceptable control performance with one uncontrollable actuator. Since partial actuator failures cannot be maintained by compensating controllers, we have to check the redundancy of the control system and determine the necessity of the faulty actuator before the control reconfiguration.

div.head: Fault identification scheme
div.p: Without considering the common-failure [44], a data-driven based process identification scheme is proposed to diagnose specific fault sites by evaluating the residual signal of the virtual system. The new procedure based on Fig. 2 designs residuals with desired performance indices and arranges residual calculations corresponding to the control strategy, and thus it is suitable for the automated implementation of the practical process.

As presented in Fig. 2, the primary procedure of the process identification scheme is to detect faults, identify fault types, and further diagnose specific fault sites. To prevent false alarms, the process identification is performed sequentially from the sensor to the actuator. Besides, the single residual generator is constructed to avoid producing indecisive results due to the oversensitivity. When an alarm occurs from the process monitoring model at the time-step k, the procedure first computes the sensor residual r sen to identify the fault type. If a sensor fault is identified, the program calculates the diagnosis oriented sensor residual r sen,dia to determine the specific fault site. When the sensor residual r sen stays within its threshold, the actuator residual r act is computed to identify if the factory has an uncontrollable actuator. Similar to the above programs, the diagnosis oriented actuator residual r act,dia is calculated to determine the specific uncontrollable actuator when an actuator failure is detected, or the alarm is determined to be a fault of process disturbance. The diagnostic sequence of the process identification scheme is related to the control strategy, and thereby the system will not fail due to the control gain reconfiguration when a false alarm occurs.

div.head: Digital twin architecture
div.p: Integrating fault identification scheme with residual design models, we present an automatic digital twin system integrated into the Safety Instrumented System (SIS) to guarantee stable controls and safe productions in faulty cases. Proposed digital twin architecture is based on the actual systems with linear parameter deviations. We combine four major aspects for digital twin modeling: (A) virtual system modeling and residual computing, (B) residual evaluation and process monitoring, (C) process diagnosis and fault identification, and (D) tolerant control and online optimization. The virtual system mirrors the physical process system virtually by using holistic simulations to build offline models for the part (B), (C), and (D). The framework developed in Fig. 3 provides the relationship among each primary part of the proposed system.

Through adaptive closed-loop SIMs, the virtual system is first identified according to the history fault-free dataset. When the system output at the time-step k is received, the residual signal r(k) is computed by comparing the predictive output from the virtual system with real outputs. Based on the residual signal r(k), the process monitoring module evaluates the residual signal and determines the status of the system. When the residual signal r(k) exceeds the threshold J th , the system alerts, then the system identifies the fault type and diagnoses the specific fault location, and the independently optimized control configurations are automatically exploited to guarantee the process performance within an admissible range. When the residual signal r(k) stays within its threshold, the system maintains stable controls based on the fault-free control gain. Besides, it is necessary to recognize that most faults can be tolerated within an acceptable limit, while few serious faults require an emergency shutdown and immediate repair. All system modules are applied simultaneously to guarantee the safe and stable production and prevent the fault from evolving into a severe accident.

div.head: Description of TE benchmark process
div.p: TE process model is a realistic simulation program of chemical plants and is widely accepted as a benchmark for control and monitoring studies [45]. The flow diagram of the TE process is shown in Fig. 4, which comprises five significant units: reactor, condenser, compressor, separator, and stripper. A complete process contains 41 process variables and 12 manipulated variables. According to the chemical production process, a revised Simulink code is available to simulate the plant's closed-loop behavior [46]. Therefore, the simulator modified in Ref. [47] is used in this research. Based on the simulator, the operation modes, measurement noises, sampling times and magnitudes of the faults can be flexibly modified to generate a dataset for the process control study.

To avoid computational overheads, we divide the simulated measurements into multiple meaningful blocks. In this work, the establishing process of digital twin systems is demonstrated by a stripper block shown in the red box in Fig. 4. As listed in Tables 1 and 2, the stripper block has three manipulated variables as inputs and six process variables as outputs. Meanwhile, Table 3 lists the process disturbances associated with the stripper. The appropriate flow rate, pressure, temperature, and level are critical control targets for the safe and stable operation. Note that using the linear model (1) for constructing a plant with highly nonlinear features may not obtain good residual estimation. However, if the process is nearly linear, the difficulty of high-dimensional variables can be addressed by multi-block solutions. To guarantee satisfactory control performances, we also consider some other process variables and manipulated variables, which are demonstrated in Section 5.3. Furthermore, the process variable XMEAS (19) and manipulated variable XM0V( 9) are removed due to the zero value. In the simulation, the sampling period is 0.6 min and the simulated time is 40 h. Both inputs and outputs of the stripper are normalized concerning their mean and standard deviations. According to Eq. (6), we first construct the virtual observer based on the original PID-type controllers under the stable operating condition. Setting the value of s for six process outputs to 14, 12, 5, 5, 6, and 9, we identify the Γ ⊥ s,i and Γ ⊥ s,i H u,s,i of each residual generator by Eq. (3). Finally, the matrices

are obtained by combining with six adaptive residual generators. Each fault model will present itself as a significant deviation in the temperature, and thus we characterize the control performance by monitoring the abnormal fluctuations in the stripper temperature. The temperature estimation predicted by the virtual system is shown in Fig. 5(a) and the residual signal between the measurement and its estimation is denoted in Fig. 5(b). In the fault-free case, the residual signal fluctuates around zero with a minor error. Accordingly, the virtual system can be applied to process monitoring, diagnosis, and optimized control.

div.head: Fault scenarios modeling and performance evaluating
div.p: Four kinds of fault scenarios are simulated based on the original PID-type controllers to present the control performance of the proposed digital twin system. The process measurements and estimations in the case of various process faults are shown in Fig. 6. In this work, we introduce the process faults at 5 h. The XMEAS(4) sensor fault is considered as an additive fault with an additional 0.2 output, while the XMV(3) actuator failure is denoted as an uncontrollable fault with fixed 80 outputs. Besides, a broader discussion on the problem of multi-fault scenarios is provided in which the XMEAS(4) sensor fault and the IDV (1) process disturbance co-occur.

As shown in Fig. 6, the PID feedback controller has a specific ability to regulate most of the process deviations caused by disturbances and device faults, except for actuator failures. The deviation between measurements and estimations reflects the severity of process faults. Since the virtual system is constructed based on the fault-free case data, excessive interference will result in significant deviations. During the system instability, process faults are most likely to evolve into catastrophic accidents, such as fires and explosions, requiring special attention.

To achieve safe productions in process industries, the digital twin system should detect and diagnose faults as early as possible and maintain the process performance within acceptable limits in faulty cases. Two generally used indices, i.e., fault detection rate (FDR) and false alarm rate (FAR), are considered as Eq. (39) for evaluating the performance of the process monitoring and diagnosis [11,48]. False alarms are alarms that are raised when the process variable is behaving normally, while fault detections express no alarm is raised when the process variable is behaving abnormally. An excessive FAR indicates a large number of false alarms would unnecessarily disturb operators. A high value of FDR implies the designed functionality of process monitoring and diagnosis systems would be severely degraded.
div.formula: FDR = ∫ J th 0 p(J res )dJ res FAR = ∫ +∞ J th q(J res )dJ res (39)
div.p: where p(J res ) and q(J res ) denote the probability density functions (PDF) of residual statistics J res in the abnormal and normal conditions respectively. The first step for calculating the FDR and FAR values is to estimate the probability density for J res in both normal and abnormal cases. Since the closed-loop feedback controller has modest fault tolerance capabilities, the critical step to estimate probability density is to separate the normal and abnormal sections of J res . According to [48], the PDFs of J res in the normal and abnormal conditions are estimated by the mean-change point detection and kernel density estimation (KDE). And finally, based on the PDFs, the FDR and FAR can be computed.
Furthermore, a security index (SI) is designed to evaluate the control capability of the processing system to survive plausible contingencies without interruptions [49].
div.formula: SI = ∑ m i=1 σ 2 i,MV ∑ m i=1 σ 2 i × 100% (40
div.p: where σ 2 i,MV is the minimum variance computed based on the ith faulty-free process output, σ 2 i is the actual variance extracted from the ith measured samples. The mean value in the variance calculation is set to the set-point of process outputs. A high value of SI implies that the control system would tolerate contingencies without an emergent interruption.

div.head: Sensor fault scenarios
div.p: After the XMEAS(4) sensor fault occurs, the virtual system modeled by Eq. ( 7) is applied to evaluate the residual signal r(k) for the process monitoring and diagnosis. According to Eq. (8), the evaluated residual criterion function J res and the corresponding threshold J th are denoted in the first plot of Fig. 7. It can be seen from Fig. 7(a) that the fault is successfully detected. Simultaneously, the sensor fault is detected by evaluating the sensor residual r sen according to Eq. (12), and the XMEAS(4) sensor is diagnosed by Eq. (16) as shown in Fig. 7(b). Based on all the detected change points and J th = 6.29, the system status from 7.22 h to 14.46 h is recognized as the fault status. Two PDFs in the normal and abnormal conditions are estimated via KDE, thereby the FDR is 6.76% and the FAR is 0.83% by Eq. (39). The system has excellent alarm performances and common detection effects, and therefore we can appropriately reduce the threshold J th to improve the performance of the process monitoring and diagnosis.

In this work, the primary intent is to apply normal sensor signals to estimate the fault sensor signal XMEAS (4). Based on the soft-sensor technology in Section 3.3.1, the fault sensor signal XMEAS(4) is estimated in Fig. 7(c), and the process control is optimized in Fig. 7(d) by integrating the estimated XMEAS(4) signal into the normal sensor outputs. Note that the estimated value of the fault signal is the signal characterization under fault-free conditions. The SI without soft-sensor technology is 24.2%, while the SI with soft-sensor optimized control is 95.1%. Comparing to the process monitoring results in Fig. 6(a), the control performance based on digital twins shown in Fig. 7(d) is significantly improved and is close to the faulty-free condition.

div.head: Process disturbance scenarios
div.p: When the process disturbance occurs, the virtual system is developed to detect and diagnose system status. As shown in the first plot of Fig. 8, the residual signal r(k) rapidly exceeds the threshold J th after the IDV(1) process disturbance occurs. It can be seen that the IDV(1) disturbance is adjusted over about 10 h by PID controllers. At the offline stage, the normal and abnormal data are separated based on the mean-change point detection, and two PDFs are estimated by kernel-based methods, accordingly, the FDR is 10.98% and the FAR is 3.03%. Due to closed-loop controls, the fault boundary of process disturbance is blurred, and thus the process monitoring has general performances. Although feedback control has certain fault tolerances, process disturbances may evolve into catastrophic accidents during the system instability.

Since the IDV(1) involves another manipulated variable XMV(3), manipulated variables XMV (3) (4) (7) (8) and process variables XMEAS (1) (4) (8) (12) (14) (15) ( 17) are applied to construct the residual signal by Eq. (24). We design a process controller to optimize above four manipulated variables to reduce interferences from IDV(1), while the PID controllers still control other manipulated variables. In the design of R c (z), the order of the parameter matrix R c (z) is set as o r = 7, and the Gradient Descent step γ is chosen as a small positive constant 1×10 −8 .

The reference signals of the XMEAS(1) (4) ( 14) (17) are set as dynamical signals by preset simulators, while the reference XMEAS(8) (12) (15) are set to fixed values of 65, 50, and 50 respectively. Designing appropriate LQ parameters Q 0 and R 0 by GAs, the stripper temperature with the application of the proposed optimized control scheme is demonstrated in Fig. 8(b). According to Eq. (40), the SI with PID controls is 2.7%, while the SI with optimized control is 6.97%. Our purpose is to minimize system disturbances and guarantee the system to return to steady states rapidly after a fault occurs, rather than returning to the initial state of the system. Compared to the PID control results in Fig. 6(b), the optimized control scheme eliminates disturbances during parameter adjustments and guarantees the security for the plants.

Furthermore, an optimization control case of intermittent fault IDV( 8) is introduced to discuss the universality of the proposed method. The process fault time is specified based on the residual signals, then two PDFs in the normal and abnormal conditions are estimated. Among 40 h simulations, the FDR is 11.63% and the FAR is 4.23%, which denotes the system has excellent monitoring performances. Besides, since the fault is discontinuous, the FDR is relatively high, which does not mean the diagnostic performance of the system is inadequate. Based on the above parameter matrix R c (z), the SI with PID controls is 1.78% and the SI with optimized control is 2.03%. Since the intermittent fault is random and discontinuous, the control of intermittent faults requires constant initialization for reconfiguration controllers. Therefore, the digital twin system can diagnose the intermittent faults, but cannot achieve more stable and safe control performance based on the optimized controller.

div.head: Actuator failure scenarios
div.p: As early mentioned, the virtual system is designed and developed by using the adaptive SIM described in Section 3.1. As shown in the first plot of Fig. 9, the actuator failure is successfully detected at 5 h, simultaneously, the XMV(3) actuator is diagnosed as shown in Fig. 9(b) by evaluating the actuator residual signal r act,dia . In more mentions, the PID controller is unable to completely restore the plant to a steady state when an actuator failure occurs. Through the mean-change point detection and tdistributed statistics, the system status from 5.02 h to 40 h is isolated as the fault status. Based on two PDFs in the normal and abnormal cases, the FDR is 0.17% and the FAR is 0.23%, which indicates the system has excellent monitoring and diagnosis performances for the actuator failure. When XMV(3) actuator fails and tends to be a tremendous value, the TE process needs to increase product discharge and other feed flow rates to guarantee the stability and security of the system. The primary intent of digital twins is to guarantee closed-loop stabilities and obtain certain control performances in the event of device failures, and thus we increase the value of the preset product flow rate from 22.89 to 30 to improve the controllability of the processing system.

To improve the actuator redundancy, manipulated variables XMV ( 1 A comparison study of the stripper temperature without and with the application of optimized control schemes is demonstrated in Fig. 9(c). Besides, for in-depth discussion, FTC system with performance optimization [22] is implemented for guaranteeing control performance in the event of XMV(3) actuator failures. Different from the FTC, the proposed optimized control scheme incorporates the controller reconfiguration into the online optimization. Based on the results from TE simulators, the SI with PID controls, FTC system, and optimized control scheme are given in Table 4. With the actuator reconfiguration and the online optimization, the system control performance is significantly improved, and the disturbance can be rapidly adjusted in approximately 5 h. Furthermore, online control error is effectively reduced based on Gradient Descent training. After about 5 h, the control performance with actuator failures is close to the faulty-free condition.

div.head: Multi-fault scenarios
div.p: To deeply explore the control performance of digital twins for multi-fault systems, we provide a fault scenario when the XMEAS(4) sensor fault and the IDV (1) process disturbance cooccur. As shown in Fig. 10(a), the residual signal r(k) rapidly exceeds the threshold J th at 5 h. After estimating PDFs for the normal and abnormal cases, the FDR is 9.37% and the corresponding FAR is 2.96% by Eq. (39). Compared to the monitoring results from single faults, digital twins are more sensitive to multiple fault conditions. Meanwhile, based on the soft-sensor technology, the fault sensor signal XMEAS(4) is estimated in Fig. 10(c), and the process control is optimized in Fig. 10(d) by incorporating estimated signals with optimized control schemes. All parameter configurations are the same as the case of process disturbances. Based on Eq. (40), the SI with and without the soft-sensor and optimized control is 6.48% and 2.18%, respectively. The control performance based on digital twins is significantly improved and is close to the case of process disturbances. In deep analyses, the digital twins have higher fault tolerances for sensor faults. Therefore, the system has better control abilities for some multi-fault conditions, such as sensor faults and process disturbances or sensor faults and actuator failures. For the rest of the more complex fault conditions, the plant should be treated for an emergency shutdown. Besides, we should note that the digital twin system can only diagnose a single device fault, and thus the system cannot automatically perform actuator reconfiguration when a sensor fault and an actuator failure co-occur.

div.head: Conclusions
div.p: Integrating process monitoring, diagnosis, and optimized control into a cooperative framework, we propose a data-driven digital twin system to reduce severe fluctuations and guarantee safe controls for industrial processes. Three types of process faults, i.e., sensor faults, actuator faults, and process disturbances are considered, and the corresponding fault size and temporal behavior are discussed. We develop adaptive SIM to accommodate different faults and provides accurate and timely diagnostic and controllable information by designing optimized control configurations. Different simulations have been performed using TE benchmark model in the presence of realistic fault scenarios. All simulation studies and numerical results indicate that the proposed configurations are valid for safe operations in the event of a process fault.

The significant contribution of the proposed approach is to establish an integrated system by digital twin concepts based on adaptive algorithms to identify process faults and reconfigure control parameters. Most of the existing model-matching based reconfiguration methods are limited by integrating the advantages of virtual models and adaptive algorithms, which cannot diagnose faults in time and optimize control gain. Proposed digital twins enable the controllers to make decisions and optimizations automatically based on fault information in the processing factory, hence better guarantee the safe operation of process systems. Besides, proposed digital twins construct virtual systems for process monitoring and diagnosis by using the data collected from normal processes rather than faulty processes, which makes digital twins more applicable to current process industries. The optimized control configurations can consider both reconfiguration problems of bias faults and apparatus failures, and simultaneously, the digital twins are suitable for the dynamical systems with unknown model parameters. It is worth mentioning that the digital twin is primarily developed for timely monitoring, diagnosis, and tolerance control in process factories, which can extend the operation time of any faulty plant with an acceptable performance until the next maintenance time is reached. In other words, the digital twin system shortens the downtime of factories and extend the operation time for process systems.

For complex fault scenarios, the process diagnostic performance of digital twins is slightly insufficient, so the specific fault location needs to be further judged by online instruments. However, since the proposed digital twin is robust during the periods of disturbances, the nominal performance of plants would be unaffected under false alarms. The proposed method is easy to understand and implement in the real application to process systems. Concerning the future research, more accurate fault diagnosis method would be focused, as well as an efficient distributed digital twin approach should be developed to improve the practical application performance of systems.
